Not the only entertainer in the family...| publisher=TheGenealogist.com|date=19 October 2012|accessdate= 27 September 2016| quote=John was born in 1966, the youngest of four children, to labourer Edward Bishop and his wife Kathleen Hackett.}}</ref> is an English comedian, presenter and actor, who is also known for his charity work, having raised £4.2m for [[Sport Relief 2012]].
A keen [[Association football|footballer]], Bishop played for [[Non-League football|non-League]] teams [[Hyde United F.C.|Hyde]] and [[Southport F.C.|Southport]], and was known for having an aggressive style of play. He also worked as a [[pharmaceutical sales representative]] prior to becoming a [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]]. His television debut came on ''[[The Panel (Irish TV series)|The Panel]]''. He has subsequently appeared in the [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] teen drama ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' (seasons 3-4) and in the [[Ken Loach]] film ''[[Route Irish (film)|Route Irish]]'' in addition to his own shows including ''[[John Bishop's Britain]]'' (2010–2011), ''John Bishop's Only Joking'' (2013) and ''[[The John Bishop Show]]'' (2015).
Bishop also had a regular Sunday slot on Liverpool radio station [[Radio City (Liverpool)|Radio City]] called ''Bishop's Sunday Service''.
==Early life== Bishop is the youngest of four children born to labourer Edward Bishop and wife Kathleen Hackett. He grew up mostly in [[Winsford]] and [[Runcorn|Runcorn, Cheshire]], and attended Murdishaw West Primary School and Brookvale Academy, after he and his family moved from [[Huyton|Huyton, Merseyside]].<ref name=RWWorld>{{cite news|last=Jordan|first=Barbara|title=John Bishop congratulates adults with learning disabilities on their beer|url=http://www.runcornandwidnesworld.co.uk/news/9235383.TV_comic_John_Bishop_opens_innovative_Runcorn_brewery/|accessdate=29 September 2011|newspaper=Runcorn and Widnes World|date=8 September 2011}}</ref> He briefly studied English at [[Northumbria University|Newcastle Polytechnic]]<ref name=How>{{cite book|last=Bishop|first=John|title= How Did All This Happen? |year=2013|publisher=Harper|isbn=978- 0007436125}}</ref><ref name=chroniclelive>[http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/exclusive-interview-with-john-bishop-6173399 John Bishop Interview at Newcastle Chronicle Live]. Retrieved 1 September 2014</ref> and gained a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Social Science]] from [[Manchester Metropolitan University|Manchester Polytechnic]].<ref name=mmu>[http://www.mmu.ac.uk/alumni/notable.php?a=1 Manchester Metropolitan University alumni]. Retrieved 31 August 2014</ref>
==Career==
In the 1990s, Bishop worked as a medical representative for the [[pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical]] company [[Syntex]], before leaving in 2006 to pursue a career as a full-time comedian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/comedian-john-bishop-says-tories-1429090 |title=Comedian John Bishop says Tories are failing our young |publisher=Mirror.co.uk |date=10 November 2012 |accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> He performed stand-up comedy for the first time in Manchester in October 2000, and the following year, made it to the final of all the major new act competitions, including ''[[So You Think You're Funny]]'', the ''Daily Telegraph'' Open Mic Awards, the BBC New Comedy Awards, and the City Life North West Comedian of The Year Award, which he won. In 2002, he was named best newcomer by [[BBC Radio Merseyside]], and in 2004, he won the North West Comedy Award for best stand-up.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/manchester/content/articles/2004/10/05/manchester_comedy_awards_2004_comedy_feature.shtml "North West Comedy Awards - the winners!"], BBC Manchester.</ref> In 2009, Bishop appeared as the first act on ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'' in Manchester. That year, he appeared at the [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]], where his show ''Elvis Has Left the Building'' was nominated for an "Eddie" ([[Edinburgh Comedy Awards|Edinburgh Comedy Award]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/edinburgh_and_east/8226378.stm|title=Edinburgh Comedy Awards - The Nominees|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 August 2009 | date=28 August 2009}}</ref>
In 2009, Bishop appeared in [[Channel 4]]'s series ''[[Comedy Showcase]]'' and was a contestant on ''[[Celebrity Mastermind]]''. He also appeared in [[BBC Three]] sitcom ''[[Lunch Monkeys]]'' as fireman Terry. He has appeared five times on [[BBC Radio 5 Live|5 Live's]] ''[[Fighting Talk]]'' quiz show, claiming four victories on the programme. His material is drawn from his life's experiences, including fatherhood, cycling around the world,<ref>{{cite news|last=Bishop|first=John|title=Standing up for men in Lycra: John Bishop tries pedal power|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-1350693/Standing-men-Lycra-Comedian-John-Bishop-tries-pedal-power.html|accessdate=4 March 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail}}</ref> playing semi-professional football, and working as a nightclub doorman. Bishop's first television appearance was in 2007 on the [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] topical-comedy show ''[[The Panel (Irish TV series)|The Panel]]'', where he was a regular panelist until 2008. He then went onto the [[Channel 4]] panel show ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'' before appearing on the [[BBC]]'s ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]''. In December 2009, Bishop started his own TV show on LFC TV called ''John Bishop Meets...'', where he interviewed former Liverpool football players.
In 2010, Bishop was a celebrity team captain on ''[[What Do Kids Know?]]'' with [[Rufus Hound]], [[Joe Swash]] and [[Sara Cox]] on [[Watch (TV channel)|Watch]]. He has also appeared on BBC's ''[[Mock the Week]]'', and [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]'s ''[[Act Your Age (radio series)|Act Your Age]]''. In series 3 and series 4 of ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'', Bishop portrayed [[Emily Fitch|Emily]] and [[Katie Fitch]]'s father. In 2010, Bishop appeared in [[Ken Loach]]'s ''[[Route Irish (film)|Route Irish]]'', which premiered at the [[2010 Cannes Film Festival]]. Bishop is a regular panelist on [[Sky1]] show, ''[[A League of Their Own (UK game show)|A League of Their Own]]'', as well as a stand-up/sketch show for [[BBC One]] titled ''[[John Bishop's Britain]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Bishop's Britain|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00t8wh8|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 July 2010}}</ref> On 11 July 2010, Bishop came runner-up in the second-ever game of ''How Many Peter Jones'?'' on ITV's ''[[James Corden's World Cup Live]]''. He has appeared as a panellist on [[BBC]] programmes ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'', and on ''[[QI]]''. On 28 October 2010, he also guest hosted an episode of series 40 of ''Have I Got News For You''.
On 12 February 2010, during an appearance on ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' it was revealed that prior to his TV breakthrough, Bishop had worked as a [[Warm-up comedian|warm-up]] for the show. In March 2011, Bishop and fellow comedians [[Alan Carr]], [[James Corden]], [[Catherine Tate]], and [[David Walliams]] appeared in the video for [[Take That]]'s single "[[Happy Now (Take That song)|Happy Now]]" for [[Comic Relief]]. On 24 June 2012, he appeared on ''[[Desert Island Discs]]''. On 28 August and 4 September 2012, he appeared in ''[[Accused (TV series)|Accused]]'' as Peter for two episodes. In late 2012, Bishop appeared on BBC [[genealogy]] series ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'' and on an ITV one off episode called ''[[Panto!]]'', where he starred as a local Morecambe disc jockey called Lewis Loud. As of January 2013, Bishop hosts ''John Bishop's Only Joking'' on [[Sky 1]].
On 28 July 2013, Bishop headlined the Vodafone comedy festival in Dublin's Iveagh Gardens. Before the gig, a reporter called [[Brian Boyd]] interviewed him about his recently replenished marriage and how his wife eventually found him funny again <ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/stage/comedy/my-wife-and-my-comedy-life-john-bishop-opens-up-1.1466367]</ref>
Bishop's autobiography titled ''How Did All This Happen?'' was published in October 2013 .<ref name=How /> In November 2013, he hosted the 2013 [[Royal Variety Performance]] at the [[London Palladium]] theatre in the presence of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.eabf.org.uk/2013-london-palladium|title= RVP 2013, London Palladium|date=|work=eabf.org.uk|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref>
In December 2014, he appeared in ''[[ITV Specials|A Night In with Olly Murs]]'' where he and [[Olly Murs]] had a lip-sync battle. In 2015, Bishop presented his own variety show on [[BBC One]] called ''[[The John Bishop Show]]''.
In May 2015, Bishop appeared as a special guest at the Liverpool date of Murs's [[Never Been Better Tour]] and performed "[[Troublemaker (Olly Murs song)|Troublemaker]]" with him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/showbiz-news/troublemaker-john-bishop-joins-olly-9234957|title=Troublemaker John Bishop joins Olly Murs on stage|first=Janet|last=Tansley|date=11 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
In January 2016, he took part in the BBC series ''[[Stargazing Live]]'', appearing from the [[European Astronaut Centre]], and following [[Tim Peake]]'s astronaut training programme with a simulated spacewalk, underwater.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/dyc8nw/stargazing-live--series-6---episode-1|title= Stargazing Live, Series 6 - Episode 1|work=Radio Times|first=David|last=Butcher|accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://principia.org.uk/events/stargazing-live/|title=Stargazing Live|work=Principia|accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref>
Since September 2016, Bishop has presented ''[[John Bishop: In Conversation With...]]'' for the [[W (UK TV channel)|W]] channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/reality-tv/news/a785278/john-bishop-will-channel-piers-morgan-in-his-new-interview-series/|title=John Bishop goes Piers Morgan for new interview series|date=1 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Two series have been aired: the show will return for a third series.
On 21 September 2016, Bishop was confirmed to have a role in ITV drama series ''Fearless'', which aired in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a808595/john-bishop-first-tv-acting-role-four-years-itv-new-thriller-fearless-michael-gambon-helen-mccrory/|title=John Bishop returns to TV for new ITV thriller|date=21 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
On 29 September 2016, Bishop announced that he would be going on tour for the fifth time in October and November 2017 with a show titled ''Winging It''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/live/news/2243/john_bishop_2017_tour/|title=John Bishop announces 2017 tour, 'Winging It'|first=British Comedy|last=Guide|date=29 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
==Awards== At the 2010 [[British Comedy Awards]], Bishop won the Best Male Comedy Breakthrough Artist award.<ref name=EchoBCA>{{cite news|last=Schofield|first=Ben|title=John Bishop named best Male Breakthrough comedian at British Comedy Awards|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-news/in-the-mix/2011/01/24/john-bishop-named-best-male-breakthrough-comedian-at-british-comedy-awards-100252-28041145/|accessdate=29 September 2011|newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=24 January 2011}}</ref> He became the Number 1 "Star in a reasonably priced car" on ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV Series)|Top Gear]]'' on Sunday 23 January 2011 after he appeared on the [[BBC Two]] show. He drove the [[Kia Cee'd]] around the test track in 1 minute and 42.8 seconds to become the fastest star in the latest reasonably priced car, knocking [[Tom Cruise]] off the top. Bishop's record lasted nearly half a year until being knocked off by [[Rowan Atkinson]] (1 minute 42.2 seconds) on Sunday 17 July 2011. He was also the fastest in the ''[[A League of Their Own (UK game show)|League of Their Own]]'' skeleton race, beating [[Georgie Thompson]] and [[James Corden]].
On 18 July 2014, Bishop was awarded an honorary fellowship at Liverpool John Moores University in recognition of his contribution to the arts and charity work during a ceremony at Liverpool's Anglican Cathedral.
==Charity work== On 30 March 2010, Bishop took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a [[Benefit concert|benefit show]] held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital|Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital]], filmed live at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London. In 2012, he completed a {{Convert|290|mi|adj=on}} [[triathlon]] from [[Paris]] to [[London]] in five days to raise money for the BBC charity [[Sport Relief]]. His "week of hell" began at the [[Eiffel Tower]] on 27 February, where he cycled {{Convert|185|mi}} to [[Calais]]. The next day, he rowed across the [[English Channel]] as part of a team including [[Davina McCall]], [[Andrew Flintoff]] and [[Denise Lewis]], then ran {{Convert|90|mi}} from [[Dover]] to London in three days, finishing in [[Trafalgar Square]] on 2 March. On 23 March, during the Sport Relief telethon, it was announced that his efforts had raised £4.2 million.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.sportrelief.com/whats-on/celebrity-challenges/bishops-week-of-hell |title=£4.2 million for Sport Relief |publisher=Sportrelief.com |date=2 March 2012 |accessdate=18 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120822040638/http://www.sportrelief.com/whats-on/celebrity-challenges/bishops-week-of-hell |archivedate=22 August 2012 |df= }}</ref> Also in 2012, Bishop took part in [[The Justice Collective]] for their cover of [[The Hollies]] single "[[He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother]]" for charities in aid of the Hillsborough disaster. In 2014, Bishop once again took part in [[Sport Relief]] as a team captain for the ''Clash of the Titans'' event competing against [[Sebastian Coe]] and his team.
Bishop has also competed in numerous charity football matches including playing in the Ciaran Geddes memorial match at the [[Deva Stadium]], [[Chester]], where Bishop scored two goals while playing with his brother [[Eddie Bishop|Eddie]] for [[Chester F.C.|Chester]].<ref>[http://www.chesterfc.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10786~2770471,00.html]</ref> On 27 May 2012, Bishop took part in the [[Soccer Aid]] match for [[Unicef]], playing for the England team, who won 3-1 against the Rest of the World. On 8 June 2014, he took part in his second [[Soccer Aid]] football match, again playing for England, this time losing 4-2 to the Rest of the World. On 5 June 2016, he took part in his third [[Soccer Aid]] match, playing on England's team.
In May 2014, Bishop donated £96,000 to the Hillsborough Family Support Group after being moved by personal statements delivered by the victims' families at their inquests.
On 19 April 2016, Bishop served as host for a comedy gig at the Royal Albert Hall in aid of [[Teenage Cancer Trust]].
==Personal life== Bishop has been married to his wife Melanie since 1993, with an 18-month separation that began in 2000.<ref name="mirror.co.uk">{{cite web|author=Beth Neil |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/06/11/i-spent-my-act-slagging-my-wife-after-we-split-until-she-turned-up-at-one-of-my-gigs-115875-22325543/ |title=John Bishop: We talk to TV's hottest new comedian - 3am & Mirror Online |publisher=mirror.co.uk |date=11 June 2010 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/john-bishops-break-up-hell-sobbed-3783516|title=John Bishop's break-up hell: I sobbed on the stairs while I got kids into wellies|first=Brian|last=Reade|date=29 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref> They have three sons: Joe (b. 1994), Luke (b. 1996), and Daniel (b. 1998).<ref name="mirror.co.uk" /><ref>{{Cite news |title=John Bishop: The brighter side of stand-up |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/southmanchesterreporter/news/s/1237810_john_bishop_the_brighter_side_of_standup |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=29 April 2010}}</ref> They live in [[Cheshire]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-24463329 BBC News: John Bishop: HS2 will 'kill communities'] (accessed 10 October 2013)</ref>
Bishop enjoys playing football and is an avid [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool FC]] fan, a fact frequently brought up on the show ''[[A League of Their Own (UK game show)|A League of Their Own]]'', on which he was a panelist. He has three older siblings; brother [[Eddie Bishop|Eddie]] (b. 1961) and two sisters Kathy (b. 1962) and Carol (b. 1965). Eddie, is a former professional footballer with [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers FC]] and [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City FC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnbishoponline.com/eddie-bishop/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203121346/http://www.johnbishoponline.com/eddie-bishop/|archivedate=3 February 2010|title= Our Eddie|publisher = John Bishop Online| accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> Besides Liverpool F.C., Bishop has said that he also supports [[Celtic F.C.]].
In July 2010, Bishop took part in protests against then-owners of Liverpool FC, [[Tom Hicks]] and [[George N. Gillett, Jr.|George Gillett]],<ref name=rallyecho>{{cite news|last=Weston|first=Alan|title=Mass rally to oust Tom Hicks and George Gillett from Liverpool FC|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-news/local-news/2010/07/03/mass-rally-to-oust-tom-hicks-and-george-gillett-from-liverpool-fc-100252-26777350/|accessdate=29 September 2011|newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=3 July 2010}}</ref> and later took part in a celebrity-studded protest video put out on YouTube.<ref name=YTEcho>{{cite news|last=Traynor|first=Luke|title=Hollywood film producer Mike Jeffries to launch anti Tom Hicks and George Gillett Liverpool FC campaign|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-entertainment/liverpool-celebrities/john-bishop/2010/09/30/hollywood-film-producer-mike-jefferies-to-launch-anti-tom-hicks-and-george-gillett-liverpool-fc-campaign-100252-27370109/|accessdate=29 September 2011|newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=30 September 2010}}</ref> Bishop pre-recorded a video message to the 2011 [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] conference, which was being held in [[Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolconfidential.co.uk/News-and-Comment/The-Laz-Wordon-the-Labour-Party-Conference |title=The Laz Word...on the Labour Party Conference |publisher=Liverpool Confidential |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=18 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627165237/http://www.liverpoolconfidential.co.uk/News-and-Comment/The-Laz-Wordon-the-Labour-Party-Conference |archivedate=27 June 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Bishop has been a [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian]] for over 20 years.<ref>{{cite web|last=Midgley |first=Carol |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2011-07-27/interview-john-bishop |title=Interview: John Bishop |publisher=''Radio Times'' |date=27 July 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> He talked about this on BBC Two's ''[[Something for the Weekend (2000s BBC TV series)|Something for The Weekend]]'' and his episode on food on his stand-up show ''John Bishop's Britain''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00jjjx4 |work= John Bishop's Britain, Series 2, Food |title=John tells his parents he's a vegetarian |publisher=BBC One |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> On a 2013 episode of ''[[The Jonathan Ross Show]]'', he said he had been vegetarian for 27 years. In 2013, [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] declared him to be one of the "Sexiest Vegetarians" of the year.<ref>"[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/bishop-cole-sexiest-vegetarians-29874851.html Bishop, Cole Sexiest Vegetarians]," ''Belfast'' ''Telegraph'', 30 December 2013.</ref>
In September 2016, Bishop was ranked tenth place on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}} Top 10 Highest Paid Comedians List where he had earned £5.4 million a year, making him the UK's highest earning comedian.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2016/09/27/25866/john_bishop_is_uks_highest_earning_comic|title=John Bishop is UK's highest earning comic : News 2016 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|first=Powder Blue Internet Business|last=Solutions|publisher=}}</ref>
